Comedy or Drama Series]] | [[Erinn Hayes]] | {{nom}} | |- |} == Related projects == The mock [[television advertisement]]s presented with the [[Adult Swim]] broadcasts of ''Childrens Hospital'' season one tied into future Adult Swim programs. A commercial for a crime procedural parody led to the show ''[[NTSF:SD:SUV::]]'' (''National Terrorism Strike Force: San Diego: Sport Utility Vehicle''), which ran from 2011 to 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/11/adult-swim-picks-up-crime-drama-parody-series-with-12-episode-order/ |title=Adult Swim Picks Up Crime Drama Parody Series With 12-Episode Order |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=November 23, 2010 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Mail.com Media|PMC]] |accessdate=July 19, 2011 |quote=The network has handed a 12-episode order to Paul Scheer's ''NTSF:SD:SUV::'' which, as the title suggests, is a parody of the ubiquitous genre of crime procedurals. […] The project leapfrogged the pilot stage, going from the clip, directed by Eric Appel, straight to series.}} Similarly, a commercial featuring [[Chris Elliott]] promoting a fictional health drink called "Nutricai" turned out to be a tie-in with an episode of the upcoming series ''[[Eagleheart (TV series)|Eagleheart]]'', one episode of which featured Elliott's character joining a [[multi-level marketing]] business selling the product. Some episode of ''Childrens Hospital'' featured a fictional TV show called ''Newsreaders,'' a parody of the CBS show ''[[60 Minutes]];'' this led to ''[[Newsreaders]]'' being picked up as its own show on Adult Swim, premiering in January 2013.{{cite video |date=November 20, 2012 |title=Newsreaders: Series Teaser |url=http://video.adultswim.com/promos/newsreaders-series-teaser.html |medium= |publisher=Adult Swim |location= |accessdate=November 23, 2012 |quote=A new spinoff of Childrens Hospital is happening and answers all of your questions about everything, because it's an interview show and that's what it's about. Watch the series premiere January 17th on Adult Swim!}}{{cite web |url=http://thefutoncritic.com/showatch/newsreaders/listings/ |title=Shows A-Z – newsreaders on adult swim |work=The Futon Critic |accessdate=January 18, 2013 |quote=Premieres Thursday, January 17 […] TIME SLOT: thursdays from 11:59 PM-12:15 AM EST}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2012/05/16/adult-swim-announces-largest-programming-schedule-ever-for-2012-13-363412/20120516adultswim01/ |title=Adult Swim Announces Largest Programming Schedule Ever for 2012–13 |date=May 16, 2012 |accessdate=May 17, 2012 |format=press release |publisher=Adult Swim}} Former ''[[The Daily Show|Daily Show]]'' co-executive producer Jim Margolis served as [[showrunner]], developing the series with ''Childrens Hospital'' creators Wain, Corddry, and Jonathan Stern.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/Checking_In_With_Childrens_Hospital_Interview_With_Rob_Corddry/7810933 |title=Checking In With 'Childrens Hospital': Interview With Rob Corddry |first=Sam |last=Morgan |date=June 23, 2011 |work=Hollywood.com |accessdate=July 19, 2011 |quote=We’re writing a Childrens Hospital movie. It will have nothing to do with the show. It’s really just the same cast and creative team.}} In 2011, Corddry stated that the cast and creative team of ''Childrens Hospital'' were working on doing a movie together, separate from ''Childrens Hospital'', with a different story and characters. In 2017, Corddry announced that a spin-off series of ''Childrens Hospital'' was in development: a global mystery/thriller structured around a season-long serial narrative.{{cite web|last1=Kozell|first1=Isaac|title=Rob Corddry on ‘Ballers,’ His ‘Childrens Hospital’ Spin-Off, and Playing Second Banana|url=http://splitsider.com/2017/09/rob-corddry-on-ballers-his-childrens-hospital-spin-off-and-playing-second-banana/|website=Splitsider|accessdate=2 October 2017|date=8 September 2017|quote=I will say that yes, there is a spin-off of ''Childrens Hospital'' that has been picked up and is in the works. We’re hard at work on writing it right now. […] And where it [''Childrens Hospital''] all took place in a children’s hospital, this is going to be kind of a global thriller from country to country.}} The new series is to feature a number of the original cast, and share the comedic tone of ''Childrens Hospital'', but will be unlike ''Childrens'' in most other respects.{{cite web|last1=Sorokach|first1=Josh|title=Rob Corddry On Inventing Binge-Watching, His ‘Childrens Hospital’ Spinoff, & Sharing Meditative Moments With Steve Guttenberg|url=https://decider.com/2017/09/14/rob-corddry-on-inventing-binge-watching-his-childrens-hospital-spinoff-sharing-meditative-moments-with-steve-guttenberg/|website=Decider|accessdate=2 October 2017|date=14 September 2017|quote=Where we shunned continuity [in ''Childrens Hospital''], this is an episodic show that solves a mystery by the end. And what we’re trying to do is actually write a compelling mystery that would be cool without the comedy.}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.adultswim.com/videos/childrens-hospital ''Childrens Hospital''] at Adultswim.com * [http://www.thewb.com/shows/childrens-hospital-on-dvd ''Childrens Hospital''] at TheWB.com *{{IMDb title|1325113}} *{{Tumblr|childrenshospitaltv|Childrens Hospital}} *{{tv.com show|childrens-hospital-with-rob-corddry}} * [http://www.adultswimcentral.com/swimcast/onehundredthree.mp3 The Swimcast] – interview with Rob Corddry, July 15, 2010 {{Adult Swim original programming}} {{EmmyAward Short-Format Live-Action Entertainment Program}} {{Williams Street|state=collapsed}} [[Category:2008 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2008 American television series endings]] [[Category:2008 web series debuts]] [[Category:2008 web series endings]] [[Category:2000s American black comedy television series]] [[Category:2000s American medical television series]] [[Category:2000s American satirical television series]] [[Category:2010 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2016 American television series endings]] [[Category:2010s American black comedy television series]] [[Category:2010s American medical television series]] [[Category:2010s American satirical television series]] [[Category:Adult Swim original programs]] [[Category:Television series by Warner Bros. Television]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:Television shows set in Brazil]] [[Category:Television series based on Internet properties]] [[Category:American web series]] [[Category:Television series by Williams Street]] [[Category:Pediatrics in the United States]]

{{unreferenced|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox political party |country = Portugal |name = Citizenship and Christian Democracy |native_name = ''Cidadania e Democracia Cristã'' |colorcode = #000080 |logo = Logo Portugal pro Vida.png |leader = [[Joana Câmara Pereira]] |foundation = {{start date|df=yes|2009|7|1}} |ideology = [[Conservatism]]
{{nowrap|[[Social conservatism]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Christian democracy]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Catholic social teaching]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Confessional state|Confessionalism of the state]]}}
{{nowrap|[[Populism]]}} |position = [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] |headquarters = Rua 24 de Junho, n.º 1497 {{nowrap|4800-076 [[Guimarães]]}} |youth_wing = |membership = ''No information'' |international = ''None'' |european = ''None'' |europarl = ''None'' |colours = [[Navy blue]] |website = [http://portugalprovida.blogspot.pt/ Official Portugal pro Vida blog] |seats1_title = [[Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)|Assembly of the Republic]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|230|hex=#000080}} |seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|21|hex=#000080}} |seats3_title = [[Autonomous regions of Portugal|Regional Parliaments]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|104|hex=#000080}} |seats4_title = [[List of municipalities of Portugal|Local
government]] |seats4 = {{Composition bar|0|2078|hex=#000080}} }} The '''Citizenship and Christian Democracy''' ({{lang-pt|Cidadania e Democracia Cristã}}, '''PPV/CDC''') is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] minor [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] [[political party]], with an ideological foundation of [[pro-life]], [[conservatism]] and [[Christian democracy]]. PPV is a newly established Portuguese political party, approved by the Constitutional Court on July 1, 2009, which defends the principles of the [[Catholic social teaching|social doctrine of the Church]]. Composed by people from all political persuasions, although mostly from the conservative right, the Portugal Pro-Life presents its programme of policy proposals around the unconditional defence of life, understanding the concept of life and the various principles inherent to it as advocates [[Catholic social teaching|Catholic Church doctrine]], and [[Roman Catholicism]] as a [[state religion]]. Its [[general manager]], elected in January 2014, is Joana Câmara Pereira. The PPV/CDC advocates the repeal of [[abortion]] law, of the recent amendments to the law of [[divorce]] found in Portugal, and to maintain prohibition of [[euthanasia]], or the revision of standards on [[sex education]] in schools, allowing parents to have an active voice. During the debate on the legalization of civil [[same-sex marriage]], the party has a position against. In the field of citizenship, the party advocates vow no age limit and the recognition of [[Conscientious objector|conscientious objection]] of taxpayers - the latter should be able to specify which use to give their taxes. ==Election results== ===Assembly of the Republic=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:100%; line-height:16px;" |- ! rowspan="2" width="50px"| Election ! colspan="3"| [[Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)|Assembly of the Republic]] ! rowspan="2" width="125px"| Government ! rowspan="2" width="40px"| Size ! rowspan="2" | Leader |- ! width="85px"| Votes ! width="50px"| % ! width="100px"| Seats won |- ! [[Portuguese legislative election, 2011|2011]] | 8,209 | 0.15% | {{Composition bar|0|230|hex=#00AAAA}} | style="background-color:#FFCCCC"| No seats | '''14''' | [[Joana Câmara Pereira]] |- ! [[Portuguese legislative election, 2015|2015]] | 2,685 | 0.05% | {{Composition bar|0|230|hex=#00AAAA}} | style="background-color:#FFCCCC"| No seats | '''19''' | [[Joana Câmara Pereira]] |} {{Portuguese political parties}} [[Category:2009 establishments in Portugal]] [[Category:Abortion in Portugal]] [[Category:Catholic political parties]] [[Category:Organizations that oppose same-sex marriage]] [[Category:Christian democratic parties in Europe]] [[Category:Conservative parties in Portugal]] [[Category:Organisations based in Guimarães]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2009]] [[Category:Political parties in Portugal]] [[Category:Right-wing populist parties]] [[Category:Social conservative parties]] {{Portugal-party-stub}}

{{Infobox organization | logo = | key_people = Michael Sapienza, [[Chief Executive Officer]]
John Backus, Chair, Board of Directors
Carmen Marc Valvo, Vice Chair, Board of Directors | name = Colorectal Cancer Alliance | founded_date = 1999 | location = Colorectal Cancer Alliance
[[Washington, D.C.]] | origins = [[Washington, D.C.]] | area_served = [[United States]] | focus = "To empower a nation of allies who work with us to provide support for patients and families, caregivers, and survivors; to raise awareness of preventative measures; and inspire efforts to fund critical research. "{{Cite web |title= Mission |url= https://www.ccalliance.org/about-us/ |work= Colorectal Cancer Alliance website |accessdate= 2017-04-12 |deadurl= no}} | method = [[Patient support]], [[Cancer research]], [[Public policy (law)|public policy]], [[education]] and [[preventive medicine|prevention]]. | revenue = | endowment = | num_employees = 41 | homepage = [https://www.ccalliance.org/ ccalliance.org] }} '''Colorectal Cancer Alliance''' is the largest and oldest [[colorectal cancer]] [[non-profit organization]] in the US. The Colorectal Cancer Alliance offers a variety of patient support services including grant programs, monthly webinars, a helpline, chat forum and a Buddy Program, which provides both survivors and caregivers with a chance to connect with someone who has gone through a similar experience. The organization serves as a source of information about colorectal health. The Colorectal Cancer Alliance also distributes colorectal cancer awareness merchandise and printed materials. The organization received its sixth straight 4-star rating from [[Charity Navigator]], and maintains the 'Accredited Charity' status from the [[Better Business Bureau]]. The organization is tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. It is eligible to receive contributions deductible as charitable donations for federal income tax purposes.{{cite web|title=COLORECTAL CANCER ALLIANCE RECEIVES 4-STAR CHARITY NAVIGATOR RATING FOR THIRD STRAIGHT YEAR|url=http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2014/05/08/634636/10080815/en/Colon-Cancer-Alliance-Receives-4-Star-Charity-Navigator-Rating-For-Fourth-Year.html|publisher=Global News Wire}}{{cite web|title=Charity Review: Colorectal Cancer Alliance|url=http://www.give.org/charity-reviews/national/cancer/colon-cancer-alliance-in-washington-dc-19043|publisher=Give.org}} ==History== The Colorectal Cancer Alliance was founded in March 18, 1999, as the Colon Cancer Alliance, after being incorporated in the state of [[Delaware]]. Its foundation was the result of a group of 41 survivors, caregivers and friends "who saw the need to educate the public about colon cancer and provide support to those affected by the disease."{{cite web|title=History & Founders: Colorectal Cancer Alliance|url=https://www.ccalliance.org/about-us/history-and-founders/|publisher=Colon Cancer Alliance}} The organization's first annual meeting occurred in Washington, DC, after which a new board of directors took office. In early 2016, the Colon Cancer Alliance merged with the [[Chris4Life Colon Cancer Foundation]], a research-focused colon cancer nonprofit organization founded in 2010. After the merger, the Colon Cancer Alliance retained its name, and became the largest colorectal cancer-focused nonprofit organization in the United States. As of November 1, 2017, the foundation was officially re-branded as the Colorectal Cancer Alliance.{{cite web|title=Colon Cancer Alliance Announces Corporate Name Change|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2017/11/02/1173511/0/en/Colon-Cancer-Alliance-Announces-Corporate-Name-Change.html|publisher=GlobeNewswire}} ==Programs and Services== The Colorectal Cancer Alliance provides services in the areas of patient and family support, research funding and prevention efforts. The organization also promotes the [[National Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month]] observed on March of every year, and the [[Dress in Blue Day]], held on the first Friday of every March. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.ccalliance.org/ Colorectal Cancer Alliance Website] * [https://www.guidestar.org/profile/86-0947831 Guidestar Report on Colorectal Cancer Alliance including financial data] * [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChk_2XJ0-AcqeSfvyBrAANA Colorectal Cancer Alliance YouTube Channel] {{Subject bar |portal1= Medicine |portal2= Health}} [[Category:Cancer charities in the United States]] [[Category:Support groups]] [[Category:Patients' organizations]] [[Category:Cancer organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Colorectal cancer]] [[Category:Charities based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1999]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|De Quervain's thyroiditis}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = de Quervain Syndrome | pronounce = {{IPA-fr|də kɛʁvɛ̃}} | synonyms = BlackBerry thumb, texting thumb, gamer's thumb, washerwoman's sprain, radial styloid tenosynovitis, de Quervain disease, de Quervain's tenosynovitis, de Quervain's stenosing, designer's thumb | tenosynovitis, mother's wrist, mommy thumb Field= [[Plastic surgery]] | image = Finkelstein Test Arrow.jpg | caption = The modified [[Eichoff maneuver]], commonly called the [[Finkelstein's test]]. The arrow mark indicates where the pain is worsened in de Quervain syndrome.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Campbell |first1=William Wesley |last2=DeJong |first2=Russell N. |title=DeJong's the Neurologic Examination |date=2005 |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |isbn=9780781727679 |page=583 |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=CvgxUpZ7ZfUC&pg=PA583 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=I2007>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ilyas A, Ast M, Schaffer AA, Thoder J |title=De quervain tenosynovitis of the wrist |journal=[[J Am Acad Orthop Surg]] |volume=15 |issue=12 |pages=757–64 |year=2007 |pmid=18063716}}</ref> | symptoms = Pain at the outside of the [[wrist]]<ref name=OI2013/> | complications = | onset = Gradual<ref name=Hub2018/> | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = Repetitive movements, [[pregnancy]], trauma, [[rheumatic diseases]]<ref name=Hub2018/><ref name=OI2013/> | diagnosis = Based on symptoms and [[physical examination|examination]]<ref name=OI2013/> | differential = [[Osteoarthritis]]<ref name=Hub2018/> | prevention = | treatment = Avoiding activities that bring on the symptoms, pain medications, [[splint (medicine)|splinting]] the thumb<ref name=Hub2018/> | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = c. 1%<ref name=Sat2018>{{cite book |last1=Satteson |first1=Ellen |last2=Tannan |first2=Shruti C. |title=De Quervain Tenosynovitis |date=2018 |publisher=StatPearls Publishing |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK442005/ |chapter=De Quervain Tenosynovitis|pmid=28723034}}</ref> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''De Quervain syndrome''' is [[inflammation]] of two [[tendon]]s that control movement of the [[thumb]] and their [[tendon sheath]].<ref name=OI2013/> This results in pain at the outside of the [[wrist]].<ref name=OI2013/> Pain is typically increased with gripping or rotating the wrist.<ref name=OI2013/> The thumb may also be difficult to move smoothly.<ref name=Hub2018/> Onset of symptoms is gradual.<ref name=Hub2018>{{cite journal |last1=Hubbard |first1=MJ |last2=Hildebrand |first2=BA |last3=Battafarano |first3=MM |last4=Battafarano |first4=DF |title=Common Soft Tissue Musculoskeletal Pain Disorders. |journal=Primary care |date=June 2018 |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=289-303 |doi=10.1016/j.pop.2018.02.006 |pmid=29759125}}</ref>
<!-- Risk factors and diagnosis --> Risk factors include certain repetitive movements, [[pregnancy]], trauma, and [[rheumatic diseases]].<ref name=Hub2018/><ref name=OI2013>{{cite web |title=De Quervain's Tendinosis - Symptoms and Treatment - OrthoInfo - AAOS |url=https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/en/diseases--conditions/de-quervains-tendinosis/ |accessdate=21 June 2018 |date=December 2013}}</ref> The diagnosis is generally based on symptoms and [[physical examination]].<ref name=OI2013/> It is supported if pain increases when the wrist is bent [[ulnar deviation|inwards]] while a person is grabbing their thumb within a fist.<ref name=Hub2018/>
<!-- Treatment and epidemiology --> Treatment involves avoiding activities that bring on the symptoms, pain medications such as [[NSAIDs]], and [[splint (medicine)|splinting]] the thumb.<ref name=Hub2018/> If this is not effective [[corticosteroid|steroid injections]] or surgery may be recommended.<ref name=Hub2018/> The condition affects about 0.5% of males and 1.3% of females.<ref name=Sat2018/> Those who are middle aged are most often affected.<ref name=OI2013/> It was first described in 1895 by [[Fritz de Quervain]].<ref name=Sat2018/>
==Signs and symptoms== Symptoms are pain at the radial side of the wrist, spasms, tenderness, occasional burning sensation in the hand, and swelling over the thumb side of the wrist, and difficulty gripping with the affected side of the hand. The onset is often gradual.<ref name=I2007/> Pain is made worse by movement of the thumb and wrist, and may radiate to the thumb or the forearm.<ref name=I2007 />
==Causes== [[File:Young people texting on smartphones using thumbs.JPG|thumb|Young people using their [[smartphones]] with their thumbs.]] The cause of de Quervain's disease is not established. Evidence regarding a possible relation with occupational risk factors is debated.<ref name="Andreu2011" /><ref name="ONeill2008">{{cite book|last=O'Neill|first=Carina J|editor=Frontera, Walter R |editor2=Siver, Julie K |editor3=Rizzo, Thomas D|title=Essentials of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Musculoskeletal Disorders, Pain, and Rehabilitation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FiMoQ-OtbB0C&pg=PA129|accessdate=9 August 2013|year=2008|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-1-4160-4007-1|pages=129–132|chapter=de Quervain Tenosynovitis}}</ref> A systematic review of potential risk factors discussed in the literature did not find any evidence of a causal relationship with occupational factors.<ref name=Stahl2013>{{cite journal|last=Stahl|first=Stéphane|author2=Vida, Daniel |author3=Meisner, Christoph |author4=Lotter, Oliver |author5=Rothenberger, Jens |author6=Schaller, Hans-Eberhard |author7= Stahl, Adelana Santos |title=Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis on the Work-Related Cause of de Quervain Tenosynovitis|journal=Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery|date=December 2013| volume=132|issue=6| pages=1479–1491|doi=10.1097/01.prs.0000434409.32594.1b| pmid=24005369}}</ref> However, researchers in France found personal and work-related factors were associated with de Quervain's disease in the working population; wrist bending and movements associated with the twisting or driving of screws were the most significant of the work-related factors.<ref name="pmid21431276">{{cite journal | vauthors = Petit Le Manac'h A, Roquelaure Y, Ha C, Bodin J, Meyer G, Bigot F, Veaudor M, Descatha A, Goldberg M, Imbernon E | title = Risk factors for de Quervain's disease in a French working population | journal = Scandinavian Journal of Work, Environment & Health | volume = 37 | issue = 5 | pages = 394–401 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 21431276 | doi = 10.5271/sjweh.3160 | url = http://www.hal.inserm.fr/inserm-00679751/document }}</ref> Proponents of the view that De Quervain syndrome is a [[repetitive strain injury]]<ref name="vanTulder2007">{{cite journal |vauthors=van Tulder M, Malmivaara A, Koes B |title=Repetitive strain injury |journal=Lancet |volume=369 |issue=9575 |pages=1815–22 |date=May 2007 |pmid=17531890 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)60820-4 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/6303661_Repetitive_strain_injury/file/d912f50c5ef67d0b27.pdf}}</ref> consider postures where the thumb is held in [[Abduction (kinesiology)|abduction]] and [[Extension (kinesiology)|extension]] to be predisposing factors.<ref name="Andreu2011">{{cite journal |vauthors=Andréu JL, Otón T, Silva-Fernández L, Sanz J |title=Hand pain other than carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS): the role of occupational factors |journal=Best Pract Res Clin Rheumatol |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=31–42 |date=February 2011 |pmid=21663848 |doi=10.1016/j.berh.2010.12.001 |url=}}</ref> Workers who perform rapid repetitive activities involving pinching, grasping, pulling or pushing have been considered at increased risk.<ref name="ONeill2008"/> Specific activities that have been postulated as potential risk factors include intensive [[computer mouse]] use, [[trackball]] use,<ref name=Andreu2011/> and typing, as well as some pastimes, including bowling, golf, fly-fishing, piano-playing, sewing, and knitting.<ref name=ONeill2008/>
Women are affected more often than men.<ref name="ONeill2008" /> The syndrome commonly occurs during and after [[pregnancy]].<ref name="Allen2004">{{cite book|last1=Allen|first1=Scott D|last2=Katarincic|first2=Julia A|last3=Weiss|first3=Arnold-Peter C|editor=Leppert, Phyllis Carolyn |editor2=Peipert, Jeffrey F |title=Primary Care for Women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PiiD0iUNhlIC&pg=PA664|accessdate=9 August 2013|year=2004|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-0-7817-3790-6|page=664|chapter=Common Disorders of the Hand and Wrist}}</ref> Contributory factors may include hormonal changes, fluid retention and—more debatably—lifting.<ref name="Allen2004" /><ref name="ASSH">{{cite web |url=http://www.assh.org/handcare/Anatomy/Details-Page/ArticleID/27956/de-Quervain-syndrome |title=DE Quervain’s Tenosynovitis |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= ASSH|publisher=American Society for Surgery of the Hand |access-date= }}</ref>
==Pathophysiology== [[File:Gray424.png|thumb|The mucous sheaths of the tendons on the back of the wrist.]] De Quervain syndrome involves noninflammatory thickening of the tendons and the [[synovial sheath]]s that the tendons run through. The two tendons concerned are those of the [[extensor pollicis brevis]] and [[abductor pollicis longus]] muscles. These two muscles run side by side and function to bring the thumb away from the hand; the extensor pollicis brevis brings the thumb outwards radially, and the abductor pollicis longus brings the thumb forward away from the palm. De Quervain tendinopathy affects the tendons of these muscles as they pass from the forearm into the hand via a fibro-osseous tunnel (the first dorsal compartment). Evaluation of histopathological specimens shows a thickening and myxoid degeneration consistent with a chronic degenerative process, as opposed to inflammation.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Clarke MT, Lyall HA, Grant JW, Matthewson MH |title=The histopathology of de Quervain's disease |journal=J Hand Surg [Br] |volume=23 |issue=6 |pages=732–4 |date=December 1998 |pmid=9888670 |doi= |url=}}</ref> The pathology is identical in de Quervain seen in new mothers.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Read HS, Hooper G, Davie R |title=Histological appearances in post-partum de Quervain's disease |journal=J Hand Surg [Br] |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=70–2 |date=February 2000 |pmid=10763729 |doi=10.1054/jhsb.1999.0308 |url=}}</ref>
==Diagnosis== De Quervain syndrome is diagnosed clinically, based on history and physical examination, though diagnostic imaging such as x-ray may be used to rule out fracture, arthritis, or other causes, based on the person's history and presentation. The modified [[Eichoff maneuver]], commonly called the [[Finkelstein's test]], is a physical exam maneuver used to diagnose de Quervain syndrome.<ref name=I2007/> To perform the test, the examiner grasps and ulnar deviates the hand when the person has their thumb held within their fist.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Campbell |first1=William Wesley |last2=DeJong |first2=Russell N. |title=DeJong's the Neurologic Examination |date=2005 |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |isbn=9780781727679 |page=583 |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=CvgxUpZ7ZfUC&pg=PA583 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=I2007/> If sharp pain occurs along the distal radius (top of forearm, about an inch below the wrist), de Quervain's syndrome is likely. While a positive Finkelstein's test is often considered [[pathognomonic]] for de Quervain syndrome, the maneuver can also cause pain in those with [[osteoarthritis]] at the base of the thumb.<ref name=I2007/>
===Differential diagnosis=== [[Differential diagnoses]]<ref name="mayo_arm">{{cite web |author=Mayo Clinic |title= Arm pain: Causes |url=http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/arm-pain/MY00114/DSECTION=causes}}</ref> include: # [[Osteoarthritis]] of the first carpo-metacarpal joint # [[Intersection syndrome]]—pain will be more towards the middle of the back of the forearm and about 2–3 inches below the wrist # [[Cheiralgia paresthetica|Wartenberg's syndrome]]
==Treatment== As with many musculoskeletal conditions, the management of de Quervain's disease is determined more by convention than scientific data. A systematic review and meta-analysis published in 2013 found that corticosteroid injection seems to be an effective form of conservative management of de Quervain's syndrome in approximately 50% of patients, although more research is needed regarding the extent of any clinical benefits.<ref name=Ashraf2013>{{cite journal|last=Ashraf|first=MO|author2=Devadoss, VG|title=Systematic review and meta-analysis on steroid injection therapy for de Quervain's tenosynovitis in adults|journal=European journal of orthopaedic surgery & traumatology: orthopedie traumatologie|date=22 January 2013|pmid=23412309|doi=10.1007/s00590-012-1164-z|volume=24|issue=2|pages=149–57}}</ref> Efficacy data are relatively sparse and it is not clear whether benefits affect the overall natural history of the illness.{{Medical citation needed|date=December 2013}}
Most tendinoses are self-limiting and the same is likely to be true of de Quervain's although further study is needed.{{Medical citation needed|date=December 2013}}
Palliative treatments include a splint that immobilized the wrist and the thumb to the interphalangeal joint and anti-inflammatory medication or acetaminophen. Systematic review and meta-analysis do not support the use of splinting over steroid injections.<ref name=Cochrane2009>{{cite journal|last=Peters-Veluthamaningal|first=C|author2=van der Windt, DA |author3=Winters, JC |author4=Meyboom-de Jong, B |title=Corticosteroid injection for de Quervain's tenosynovitis|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=8 July 2009|issue=3|pages=CD005616|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD005616.pub2|pmid=19588376}}</ref><ref name=Coldham2006>{{cite journal|last=Coldham|first=F|title=The use of splinting in the non-surgical treatment of De Quervains disease: a review of the literature|journal=British Journal of Hand Therapy|year=2006|volume=11|issue=2|pages=48–55|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0023405/|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref>
Surgery (in which the sheath of the first dorsal compartment is opened longitudinally) is documented to provide relief in most patients.<ref name="pmid7963313">{{cite journal | vauthors = Weiss AP, Akelman E, Tabatabai M | title = Treatment of de Quervain's disease | journal = The Journal of Hand Surgery | volume = 19 | issue = 4 | pages = 595–8 | date = July 1994 | pmid = 7963313 | doi = 10.1016/0363-5023(94)90262-3 }}</ref> The most important risk is to the radial sensory nerve.
Some occupational and physical therapists suggest alternative lifting mechanics based on the theory that the condition is due to repetitive use of the thumbs during lifting. Physical/Occupational therapy can suggest activities to avoid based on the theory that certain activities might exacerbate one's condition, as well as instruct on strengthening exercises based on the theory that this will contribute to better form and use of other muscle groups, which might limit irritation of the tendons.
Some occupational and physical therapists use other treatments, in conjunction with Therapeutic Exercises, based on the rationale that they reduce inflammation and pain and promote healing: UST, SWD, or other deep heat treatments, as well as [[Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation|TENS]], [[acupuncture]], or infrared light therapy, and [[cold laser]] treatments. However, the pathology of the condition is not inflammatory changes to the synovial sheath and inflammation is secondary to the condition from friction.<ref name="pmid23943679">{{cite journal | vauthors = Patel KR, Tadisina KK, Gonzalez MH | title = De Quervain's Disease | journal = Eplasty | volume = 13 | issue = | pages = ic52 | date = 2013 | pmid = 23943679 | pmc = 3723064 }}</ref> Teaching patients to reduce their secondary inflammation does not treat the underlying condition but may reduce their pain; which is helpful when trying to perform the prescribed exercise interventions.
Getting Physical Therapy before surgery or injections has been shown to reduce overall costs to patients and is a viable option to treat a wide array of musculoskeletal injuries.
==History== From the original description of the illness in 1895 until the first description of corticosteroid injection by Jarrod Ismond in 1955,<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | date = Jun 1955 | title = Local hydrocortisone in de Quervain's disease | url = | journal = Br Med J | volume = 1 | issue = 4929| pages = 1501–3 | doi=10.1136/bmj.1.4929.1501 | author=Christie B. G. B.}}</ref> it appears that the only treatment offered was surgery.<ref name="ReferenceA" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Piver JD, Raney RB | date = Mar 1952 | title = De Quervain's tendovaginitis | url = | journal = Am J Surg | volume = 83 | issue = 5| pages = 691–4 | doi=10.1016/0002-9610(52)90304-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lamphier TA, Long NG, Dennehy T | date = Dec 1953 | title = De Quervain's disease: an analysis of 52 cases | doi = 10.1097/00000658-195312000-00002 | journal = Ann Surg | volume = 138 | issue = 6| pages = 832–41 | pmid = 13105228 | pmc=1609322}}</ref> Since approximately 1972, the prevailing opinion has been that of McKenzie (1972) who suggested that corticosteroid injection was the first line of treatment and surgery should be reserved for unsuccessful injections.<ref>{{cite journal | author = McKenzie JM | date = Dec 1972 | title = Conservative treatment of de Quervain's disease | url = | journal = Br Med J | volume = 4 | issue = 5841| pages = 659–60 | doi=10.1136/bmj.4.5841.659}}</ref>
===Eponym=== It is named after the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[surgery|surgeon]] [[Fritz de Quervain]] who first identified it in 1895.<ref name="pmid15576233">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ahuja NK, Chung KC |title=Fritz de Quervain, MD (1868-1940): stenosing tendovaginitis at the radial styloid process |journal=J Hand Surg [Am] |volume=29 |issue=6 |pages=1164–70 |year=2004 |pmid=15576233 |doi=10.1016/j.jhsa.2004.05.019 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0363-5023(04)00381-8}}</ref> It should not be confused with [[de Quervain's thyroiditis]], another condition named after the same person.
==Society and culture==
BlackBerry thumb is a [[neologism]] that refers to a form of [[repetitive strain injury]] (RSI) caused by the frequent use of the thumbs to press buttons on [[personal data assistant|PDAs]], [[smartphone]]s, or other [[mobile device]]s. The name of the condition comes from the [[BlackBerry]], a brand of smartphone that debuted in 1999,<ref>[https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/news/fullstory_65822.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821205306/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/news/fullstory_65822.html |date=21 August 2008 }}</ref> although there are numerous other similar [[eponymous]] conditions that exist such as "[[Wiiitis]]",<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nett MP, Collins MS, Sperling JW |title=Magnetic resonance imaging of acute "wiiitis" of the upper extremity |journal=Skeletal Radiology |volume=37 |issue=5 |pages=481–83 |year=2008 |pmid=18259743 |doi=10.1007/s00256-008-0456-1}}</ref> "[[Nintendinitis]]",<ref>{{cite journal |author=Koh TH |title=Ulcerative "nintendinitis": a new kind of repetitive strain injury |journal=The Medical Journal of Australia |volume=173 |issue=11–12 |pages=671 |date=December 2000 |pmid=11379534}}</ref> "Playstation thumb", "texting thumb",<ref>{{cite web |author=Rush University Medical Center |url=https://www.rush.edu/health-wellness/discover-health/when-technology-hurts |title='Texting thumb' and other tech-related pain, explained |publisher=Rush University Medical Center|date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=2015-04-11}}</ref> "cellphone thumb",<ref>{{cite journal |author=Karim SA |title=From 'playstation thumb' to 'cellphone thumb': the new epidemic in teenagers |journal=South African Medical Journal |volume=99 |issue=3 |pages=161–2 |date=March 2009 |pmid=19563092}}</ref> "smartphone thumb", "Android thumb", and "iPhone thumb". The medical name for the condition is De Quervain syndrome and is associated with the tendons connected to the thumb through the wrist. Causes for the condition extend beyond smartphones and gaming consoles to include activities like golf, racket sports, and lifting.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mayo Clinic Staff |url=http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/de-quervains-tenosynovitis/DS00692 |title=De Quervain's Tenosynovitis |publisher=Mayo Clinic |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-05}}</ref>
Symptoms of BlackBerry thumb include aching and throbbing pain in the thumb and wrist.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/04/22/AR2005042201739.html | work=The Washington Post | title=For Some, Thumb Pain Is BlackBerry's Stain | first=Amy | last=Joyce | date=23 April 2005 | accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref> In severe cases, it can lead to temporary disability of the affected hand, particularly the ability to grip objects.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2005/10/69294 |title=The Agony of 'BlackBerry Thumb' |publisher=Wired.com |date=21 October 2005 |accessdate=2010-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419052633/http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2005/10/69294 |archivedate=19 April 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
One hypothesis is that the thumb does not have the [[dexterity]] the other four fingers have and is therefore not well-suited to high speed [[touch typing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arthritis.webmd.com/news/20050126/BlackBerry-thumb-real-illness-just-dumb |title=BlackBerry Thumb: Real Illness or Just Dumb? |publisher=Arthritis.webmd.com |date=26 January 2005 |accessdate=2010-05-18}}</ref> {{Clear}}
== See also == * [[Mobile phone overuse]] * [[Nomophobia]]
